prefix_walkthrough:
!!! Here is a walkthrough of a text game:

==>STEP NUM: 0
==>ACT: Init
==>OBSERVATION: Copyright (C)1986 Infocom, Inc. All rights reserved.

[Press any key to begin.]
                                                                                                                                
Sharp words between the superpowers. Tanks in East Berlin. And now, reports the BBC, rumors of a satellite blackout. It's enough to spoil your continental breakfast.

But the world will have to wait. This is the last day of your $599 London Getaway Package, and you're determined to soak up as much of that authentic English ambience as you can. So you've left the tour bus behind, ditched the camera and escaped to Hyde Park for a contemplative stroll through the Kensington Gardens.

Palace Gate

A tide of perambulators surges north along the crowded Broad Walk. Shaded glades stretch away to the northeast, and a hint of color marks the western edge of the Flower Walk.
Palace Gate


==>STEP NUM: 1
==>ACT: inventory
==>OBSERVATION: You're not holding anything, but you're wearing a wristwatch. You also have a credit card and a seven-sided coin in your pocket.


==>STEP NUM: 2
==>ACT: examine watch
==>OBSERVATION: Your wristwatch says it's 3:30:00 pm.


==>STEP NUM: 3
==>ACT: take coin
==>OBSERVATION: You take the seven-sided coin out of your pocket.


==>STEP NUM: 4
==>ACT: examine coin
==>OBSERVATION: It's standard British currency, worth fifty pence.


==>STEP NUM: 5
==>ACT: east
==>OBSERVATION: The east wind makes it difficult to walk straight.

Flower Walk

Gaily colored flower beds line the walks bending north and west, filling the air with a gentle fragrance. A little path leads northwest, between the trees.

You can see a soccer ball half-hidden among the blossoms.

The spires of the Albert Memorial are all too visible to the south. Passing tourists hoot with laughter at the dreadful sight; nannies hide their faces and roll quickly away.
           Flower Walk


==>STEP NUM: 6
==>ACT: examine memorial
==>OBSERVATION: Your London guide book warned you that the Albert Memorial was ugly, but nothing could have prepared you for this embarrassing spectacle!


==>STEP NUM: 7
==>ACT: examine blossoms
==>OBSERVATION: You can see a soccer ball half-hidden among the blossoms.


==>STEP NUM: 8
==>ACT: take ball
==>OBSERVATION: You take the soccer ball off the flower beds.

[Your score just went up by 1 point. The total is now 1 out of 100.]

[NOTE: You can turn score notification on or off at any time with the NOTIFY command.]


==>STEP NUM: 9
==>ACT: northwest
==>OBSERVATION: The Wabe

This grassy clearing is only twenty feet across, and perfectly circular. Paths wander off in many directions through the surrounding thicket.

A shaft of golden sunlight falls across a handsome antique sundial, erected at the exact center of the clearing.
           The Wabe


==>STEP NUM: 10
==>ACT: examine sundial
==>OBSERVATION: The perimeter of the sundial is inscribed with seven curious symbols and a compass rose, with the legend "TEMPUS EDAX RERUM" emblazoned across the bottom. A triangular gnomon casts a fingerlike shadow that is creeping slowly towards the first symbol.
                                           "And 'the wabe' is the grass-plot round    a sun-dial, I suppose?" said Alice,       surprised at her own ingenuity.                                                    "Of course it is. It's called 'wabe,'      you know, because it goes a long way      before it, and a long way behind it --"                                                                    -- Lewis Carroll


==>STEP NUM: 11
==>ACT: examine gnomon
==>OBSERVATION: It's a triangular piece of metal, about a quarter-inch thick and four inches long, screwed into the center of the sundial.


==>STEP NUM: 12
==>ACT: unscrew gnomon
==>OBSERVATION: You can feel the gnomon getting more and more wobbly as you unscrew it. A final twist, and it falls with a clatter onto the face of the sundial.


==>STEP NUM: 13
==>ACT: take gnomon
==>OBSERVATION: You take the gnomon off the sundial.

[Your score just went up by 5 points. The total is now 6 out of 100.]


==>STEP NUM: 14
==>ACT: northwest
==>OBSERVATION: Broad Walk

A brooding statue of Queen Victoria faces east, where the waters of the Round Pond sparkle in the afternoon sun. Your eyes follow the crowded Broad Walk north and south until its borders are lost amid the bustle of perambulators. Small paths curve northeast and southeast, between the trees.

A cloud of pigeons fills the air! They circle overhead and congregate around a nearby bench, where an aged woman is selling bags of crumbs.

"Feed the birds! Thirty p!" Her voice quavers with heartbreak.
        Broad Walk


==>STEP NUM: 15
==>ACT: examine woman
==>OBSERVATION: You get the feeling that she's been selling crumbs on this same bench, year after year, since well before you were born. Her face is lined with care for her feathered charges, who perch on her round shoulders without fear.

question_step_navi:
!!! Starting from location 'Palace Gate', perform a list of action ['east', 'northwest', 'northwest'], where are you now?
Describe the trajectory in a python list of python dictionary with keys 'location_before', 'action' and 'location_after'.
The allowed actions are: ['down', 'east', 'inventory', 'north', 'northeast', 'northwest', 'open umbrella', 'push pram east', 'push pram south', 'south', 'southeast', 'southwest', 'up', 'west'].
The list of locations are: ['Flower Walk', 'Palace Gate', 'The Wabe', 'Broad Walk', 'Round Pond', 'Black Lion Gate', 'Inverness Terrace', 'Lancaster Gate', 'Lancaster Walk', 'Long Water', 'Wading', 'Meadow', 'Summit', 'South Bog', 'Bottom of Stairs', 'Halfway Up', 'Vertex'].

Answer: [{'location_before': 'Palace Gate', 'action': 'east', 'location_after':

!!! Here is a walkthrough of a text game:

==>STEP NUM: 0
==>ACT: Init
==>OBSERVATION: Copyright (C)1986 Infocom, Inc. All rights reserved.

[Press any key to begin.]
                                                                                                                                
Sharp words between the superpowers. Tanks in East Berlin. And now, reports the BBC, rumors of a satellite blackout. It's enough to spoil your continental breakfast.

But the world will have to wait. This is the last day of your $599 London Getaway Package, and you're determined to soak up as much of that authentic English ambience as you can. So you've left the tour bus behind, ditched the camera and escaped to Hyde Park for a contemplative stroll through the Kensington Gardens.

Palace Gate

A tide of perambulators surges north along the crowded Broad Walk. Shaded glades stretch away to the northeast, and a hint of color marks the western edge of the Flower Walk.
Palace Gate


==>STEP NUM: 1
==>ACT: inventory

==>STEP NUM: 3

==>OBSERVATION: You take the seven-sided coin out of your pocket.


==>STEP NUM: 4
==>ACT: examine coin
==>OBSERVATION: It's standard British currency, worth fifty pence.


==>STEP NUM: 5
==>ACT: east
==>OBSERVATION: The east wind makes it difficult to walk straight.

Flower Walk

Gaily colored flower beds line the walks bending north and west, filling the air with a gentle fragrance. A little path leads northwest, between the trees.

You can see a soccer ball half-hidden among the blossoms.

The spires of the Albert Memorial are all too visible to the south. Passing tourists hoot with laughter at the dreadful sight; nannies hide their faces and roll quickly away.
           Flower Walk


==>STEP NUM: 6

==>STEP NUM: 9

==>OBSERVATION: The Wabe

This grassy clearing is only twenty feet across, and perfectly circular. Paths wander off in many directions through the surrounding thicket.

A shaft of golden sunlight falls across a handsome antique sundial, erected at the exact center of the clearing.

==>STEP NUM: 10
==>ACT: examine sundial
==>OBSERVATION: The perimeter of the sundial is inscribed with seven curious symbols and a compass rose, with the legend "TEMPUS EDAX RERUM" emblazoned across the bottom. A triangular gnomon casts a fingerlike shadow that is creeping slowly towards the first symbol.
                                           "And 'the wabe' is the grass-plot round    a sun-dial, I suppose?" said Alice,       surprised at her own ingenuity. It's called 'wabe,'      you know, because it goes a long way      before it, and a long way behind it --"                                                                    -- Lewis Carroll

A cloud of pigeons fills the air! They circle overhead and congregate around a nearby bench, where an aged woman is selling bags of crumbs.

So you've left the tour bus behind, ditched the camera and escaped to Hyde Park for a contemplative stroll through the Kensington Gardens.

Palace Gate

It's called 'wabe,'      you know, because it goes a long way      before it, and a long way behind it --"                                                                    -- Lewis Carroll
